- Professional list maker Experience Security Engineer Arctic Wolf Networks September 2014  – Present (11 months) Sunnyvale, CA Product / Service demonstrations showcasing our ability to detect and report network threats to a prospective client and answering their questions in how they can implement our product.  
 
Manage client on-boarding (post-trial) assisting with additional sensor/honeypot installations within the network.

Program Management - ITR YouTube/Google January 2014  –  August 2014  (8 months) San Francisco Bay Area The program management experience I have is both technical as well as non-technical ranging from test network deployments to software licensing reduction efforts.  
 
'Noogler' Tech Program Manager - During my time with the “Noogler” team I was responsible for coordinating weekly new hire onboarding tasks. Weekly tasks consisted of provisioning new accounts, allocating hardware, troubleshooting account access, giving the IT presentation(s) to classes of 50-200 people, and answering general IT questions. 
 
802.1x Deployment - Worked in conjunction with various networking and telecommunication teams in order to deploy 802.1x port authentication to multiple buildings in Google Dublin and YouTube. 
 
Software Licensing Reduction - Interfacing directly with VP and Director level employees to reduce unnecessary software spending within their department. Reduced number of licensed software installs in favor of an in-house solution, and provided training to users on using the new tool(s). 
 
Test Network Deployment - Coordinated amongst networking, security and infrastructure  
teams in order to deploy a global wireless testing network for Google engineers to easily test mobile devices. On-Call Corporate Security “Ninja” - ITR Google February 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year 7 months) Mountain View, CA This is a small team of Windows host-based security ‘ninjas’ that go through daily on-call rotations for any inquiries or incidents in relation to our endpoint threat detection solution. This role has involved software and publisher based certificate revocation and auditing, whitelisting internal application builds in preparation for fleet-wide deployment, acting as an escalation point for support staff, and working closely with internal security operations teams.  
 
As a team co-lead part of my responsibilities are making sure escalations are handled in an acceptable timeframe as well as training new team members. Internal Technology Resident (ITR) Google June 2012  –  August 2014  (2 years 3 months) San Francisco Bay Area The main role of an ITR is providing 'front line' in-person and ticket-based support in a very teamwork heavy environment for a large user base, troubleshooting & solving a large variety of issues. Identifying and filing bug reports to the correct internal teams and then work with them to solve product or system issues. Act as a liaison between technical and non-technical groups to enhance Google's infrastructure and internal services at all three bay area locations. MDF/IDF Management - ITR Google/Youtube January 2014  –  May 2014  (5 months) San Francisco Bay Area I was put in charge as a co-leader for all Google SF main distribution frame operations. During this time I audited all devices and networking equipment, removed unused devices, added new equipment, as well as updated and created corporate documentation and configurations for the MDF/IDFs.  
 
I have also helped coordinate planned power outages for entire buildings, communicating this to affected teams, and then working in conjunction with them to failover devices or to properly power down servers and other equipment. Perimeters Team Security Engineer - ITR Google October 2013  –  January 2014  (4 months) Mountain View, CA During my time with the perimeters team I was responsible for modification and creation of ACLs (Cisco / Juniper) for new lab / test network requests. I interfaced directly with the teams or individuals requesting the lab and worked with them to discern their access needs to build an adequate solution.  
 
In addition to lab creation I audited existing ACLs on lab networks making sure there was no extraneous access allowed. Another responsibility was firewall (SRX) administration and policy creation for DMZ / internal systems access requests from external partners. Dublin Rotation - ITR Google July 2013  –  October 2013  (4 months) Dublin, Ireland As part of my IT Helpdesk role I traveled to the European headquarters in order to help out the local engineers with user support, network changes, device deployment, and AV maintenance needs. While I was there I trained new member of the "ninja" security team I work on, as well as helping out with new hire orientation and account activation. Co-Founder Coast to Coast Custom Computers March 2012  –  November 2012  (9 months) Rochester, New York Started a small company with the idea to "Build custom gaming rigs and powerful servers for LESS than the other guys!" We ended up working for a few individuals and one company soon after launching our site and a small advertising campaign. I helped build/update the site and act as a point of contact for our customers to answer inquiries / fulfill requests. Domain Security Analyst Intern Liberty Mutual Insurance May 2011  –  August 2011  (4 months) Portsmouth, NH While working at Liberty Mutual I created presentations educating users on security practices and risks. It was my job to take technical matters and turn them into real english that regular users could learn from and improve their security mindset. 
 
I have also participated in presentations to stakeholders about current security posture and how to develop current infrastructure. This included talking directly with key decision makers with regards to budgeting for security matters. Security Analyst Intern Paychex December 2010  –  May 2011  (6 months) Rochester, New York Area My role at Paychex involved the bridging of security and people.  
 
I worked directly with the persons affected by the incident or a representative for the company affected by the breach to find a resolution. It was my responsibility to find out what information was disclosed and put a report together.  
 
I also provided a daily security newsletters that included vulnerabilities to systems we were using (rated by the potential risk to the company), an analysis of breaches that occurred at similar companies and where we could improve to prevent that, and the occasional general interest story to help promote a security conscious mindset. 
 
In addition to the reposting and analysis, I put together a test deployment of Snort / Snorby to do security event reporting for eventual corp deployment. Jr. Systems Administrator TransAmerican CHB May 2008  –  August 2008  (4 months) Buffalo/Niagara, New York Area Worked under the senior systems admin on the day to day upkeep of a small company’s IT Infrastructure.  
 
My every day responsibilities included configuring Cisco networking equipment, provisioning user/group accounts via AD for new hires/users, and running new software/patch deployments in a test environment.  
 
I also worked on a project to deploy SSO authentication in order to consolidate the various credentials for email (Lotus Notes), login (AD), and other internal web applications. Senior Software Developer Adconion Direct July 2012  –  December 2013  (1 year 6 months) Performed software reverse engineering to disassemble and debug unknown code using IDA Pro, windbg, etc. Assessed scalability and performance issues in a high traﬃc, high transaction infrastructure (hosts with 100k+ IP aliases, DB tables with 500M+ rows, etc.) Within the ﬁrst 2 months of hire: reverse engineered a 64-bit DLL and its data ﬁle format, a 5MB 32-bit Linux binary and its encrypted network protocol, improved the execution time of edge cases of the standard Linux ip(1) tool by 70x, and automated manual processes that took hours to run in seconds. Within the ﬁrst 3.5 months: my technical expertise was the direct source of 1+ million USD of additional revenues. Principal Architect, Security Rapid7 September 2005  –  July 2012  (6 years 11 months) As Principal Architect, Security: 
 
Developed key features of NeXpose, a vulnerability assessment tool sold primarily to large corporations and government agencies. Sole engineer responsible for maintaining Rapid7's PCI ASV status (Payment Card Industry - Approved Scanning Vendor.) Advised various internal groups on technical directions. Automated Nexpose hardware Linux appliance installation. Optimized product build time from 30-40min down to 10-15min. Enhanced Nexpose's custom SMB/CIFS stack to support the latest authentication protocols, developped "pass-the-hash" in Nexpose, tied it to Metasploit. 
 
As Senior Software Engineer: 
 
Lead the team developing security checks for Nexpose. Researched distributed SCMs, switched our 2GB repository with 100k files and 20k changesets from CVS to Mercurial, trained developers. Built up a virtual machine lab from scratch that ended up having 2000+ VMs, 200+ templates, spread across 4 servers which I spec'd (total 300GB RAM, 10TB disk), all running QEMU (then KVM), with a custom web interface to manage and access VMs, which I wrote and open-sourced (Qemudo.) 
 
As Software Engineer: 
 
Research and exploitation of security vulnerabilities. Reverse engineering of Microsoft security patches and proprietary network protocols. Developped security checks for Nexpose. Took the initiative of porting Nexpose to 64-bit Linux (30k lines of C++ functions called from Java to mostly parse and craft network packets), which turned out to be a great foresight as a year later Rapid7 "urgently" needed to migrate appliance customers away from 32-bit.
